text: RICK STEVENS, thirty-six, is Middle America personified. blends in at the crowded ballpark. Blue jeans, work boots ball cap and leather jacket complete his attire. He snack a bag of popcorn. The CRACK of the bat and the CROWD is o their feet. A BALL PLAYER slides safely into second with double. JOHN SILVERSTEIN, thirty-three, business clad, ta on his cell phone. Calm and collected he appears unaffect by the cheering crowd. The sits with the crowd.
Helluva talent, that kid.
John flashes a quick grin, never missing a beat in his ph call.
Probably be in the bigs in another year.
John nods, smiles and turns away from Rick to continue uninterrupted.
MELANIE SIMMERS, twenty-four, scurries around a sparse, b neatly adorned house getting dressed.
Zach? Are you ready? Mommy, can't be late again.
ZACH SIMMERS, six, sits on his bed in pajamas.
I'm ready.
Melanie ENTERS.
Come on baby. Don't do this to mommy. Not today.
I don't want to go. Melanie hastily dresses her son.
Zach, do you want mommy to get fired?
Yes.
If I get fired we won't have the money to go to Six Flags. Zach quickly dresses himself.
John still talks on his cell.

Must be something to have that kind of talent. He's just a kid, nineteen, twenty tops, and if he stays healthy and he stays focused, the world is his oyster. Guys like you and me, we squandered those opportunities long ago.
John ends his call and turns back to Rick.
You.
Huh?
Guys like you...
And me...
... squandered opportunities. I, on the other hand, knew where I was going. I had that kind of drive, I just never had the talent.
You knew where you were going?
Absolutely.
At nineteen?
Without question.
The only thing I knew for certain was that I would run to the corner store every day for beer.
Melanie pulls into a parking space and turns the car off.
Lock your door. I'll be right back. Melanie opens her door.
Mom?
Melanie pops her head back in the car.
What?
I'm not thirteen. It's against the law to leave me alone in a car until I'm thirteen.
Come on.
Zach EXITS.
John's phone RINGS. He ignores the call.
I had priorities. I understood what it meant to have an attention span.
You could focus?
I was the King of Focus.
The Duke of Diligence?
The Count of Concentration.
Rick is still looking at John when he hears the CRACK of bat.
Duck.
Huh?

Rick ducks. John appears perplexed. John's POV: A foul ba is screaming in his direction. Too late: The ball strikes John in the face knocking him out of his seat. Rick recov and continues to snack on his popcorn.
The Polestar Prince.
Melanie carries a soda and a bag of chips. Zach stands at cooler looking through the glass.
Did you decide?
I want Coke.
Get one.
No, Pepsi. (A beat) No, Seven-Up. Maybe root beer.
Make up your mind already.
So many choices. A glance to her watch.
The game is over. Rick and John stand at the front gate. exiting CROWD flows around them. John holds an ice pack t the side of his face.
I'm just saying grow up. You can't keep drifting.
I thought I did grow up...
When you got married?
Yeah...
You matured a little.
It's a process.
No Bueller, it's a decision. One you need to make. You can't keep running without direction. If you don't know where you're going you'll never get what you want.
Melanie and Zach stand at the counter. The CLERK rings th out. Zach grabs the bottle from the counter.
I want Sobe.
Melanie snatches the bottle back.
Too bad.
An impatient LINE OF CUSTOMERS waits.
I don't want Coke. I want Sobe.
Melanie puts the bottle back on the counter.
(To clerk.) We'll take the soda.
Zach stomps his feet.
Two dollars and...
Hold on a minute. Please?
Come on lady.
A beat as Zach and Melanie exchange glares.
Get your Sobe.
The crowd has waned.
I thought I got direction...
When Cindy had kids?
Yeah...
They gave you purpose. But purpose, my friend, is not direction.
East.
Huh?
My direction is east. I parked in the deck.
I'm right around the...
Corner?
Yeah.
We're always going in different directions.
Mine are much more productive.
And much less adventurous.
Well, I'm gonna...
Go?
Yeah.
Then go.
That's what I'm going to do. Responsibility calls.
John turns and heads south. Rick takes a bite of popcorn, looks to the sky for a moment, grins, and heads off Northeast.
Zach takes a long swig of Sobe.
Sobe sucks. I want Coke.
John jogs up behind Rick.
You want to...
Get a beer?
Yeah.
Can't.
Can't?
Gotta get home.
Why?
Family, my man. Take time off for a ballgame ya should probably tend to the family too. You should try it sometime.
In the grand scheme of things family is a liability, not an asset. Rick continues on.
(Calling out.) Do you even know what you're doing or where you're going?
(Yelling over his shoulder.) East.
East leads nowhere, my friend. You should be heading south. The bar is south. East takes you places you don't want to go.
Rick reaches the corner and darts across the street.
Melanie stands in front of her BOSS (20's).
You're late.
I know, but...
No buts. You're late.
But...
It's the third time this week Mel. You put me in a rough spot here. My boss wants me to let you go. His boss wants me to let you go. I gotta let you go.
But...
If a person isn't responsible enough to be prompt to their job, they're not responsible enough to work for me.
But...
You're fired Mel. Just get your things and go.
A beat as Melanie turns to leave.
We still on for dinner?
TWO OFFICERS parked on Main watch Rick cross the street.
Is that...?
You think...?
Naw...
Officer's POV: A WANTED POSTER of Rick Stevens.
Can't tell from here...
Too far away. Let's roost him.
Call it in.
Rick walks East on Buchtel as Police cruiser creeps behin
Officer's POV: Slowly driving past, the officers recogniz Rick.
It's him... get him, get him, get him. They curb the car in front of Rick.
Rick appears dumbfounded as the officers exit the cruiser with guns drawn. Officer One remains stationary. Officer circles behind Rick.
Get em up. Up I said... up.
Huh?
Get `em where we can see `em slimeball.
Rick raises his hands, dropping his popcorn.
Oh, we got ourselves a litterbug here.
What?
Placing his pistol back in his holster Officer Two grabs by the collar and throws him against the cruiser. Officer remains drawn on Rick. His hands shake with nervous anticipation.
What's going...
Shaddup!
Officer Two cuffs Rick. Leaning in, he speaks in Rick's e
You know your rights, cretin, but just in case you don't...
What the hell? Officer Two spins Rick to face him.
You have the right to shut the hell up. Do you understand this right?
Yes.
Officer One appears very eager to discharge his weapon.
Shut him the hell up, Jimmy.
If you don't shut the hell up my partner might exercise his right to shoot you. Do you understand?
`Yes' begins to form on Rick's lips. A quick glance at Officer One and he decides to nod.
He's looking at me funny, Jimmy.
You have the right not to look at my partner in any way that might be construed as `funny' which could result in harm to your person. Do you understand this right?
Rick nods again.
He twitching?
Really? I don't think he is. Are you twitching boy?
No Sir.
Look at him, he's twitching. Nothing pisses me off more than twitching and talking. If he doesn't stop I'm gonna waste him.
You have the right not to twitch or shiver or make any other odd movements that might encourage my partner to discharge his weapon, do you understand?
Melanie grabs her stuff.
You never answered about tonight.
You're making a huge mistake.
An unmarked car pulls on scene. The door opens. Low in on walking feet and pan up to reveal DETECTIVE JOHNSON, (50' a gruff man in tweed.
What do we got here boys?
It's him. We got him.
He's a twitcher... a twitcher and a talker. Boy, I tell you, if he'd twitched one more time I would've deposited large amounts of hot lead in his ass.
I'll take it from here boys.
Report too?
No, that's your job.
If we have to write the report I say I get to shoot him.
No one's getting shot today, Bobby.
Can't I just wing him or something?
Jimmy; get him out of here.

Officer Two moves to his unwilling partner and helps him place his weapon in his holster. Officer One's hand is st clenched to his gun as Officer Two drags him around the c and forces him into the cruiser.
Melanie drives.
Tell me I'm not responsible... asshole. I have a kid. He has a goldfish. I have my dignity.
MEL ANIE (cont'd) He has a brown ring on his collar. He's nothing more than a turd with feet.
Rick is restless in the back seat. Johnson glances in the rear view mirror.
You don't want to piss Bobby off. He's a little unstable.
A little? He represents your force?
Affirmative action. We have to hire our fair share of disabled --- Quota thing.
His psychosis doesn't appear disabling.
MRS. NELSON, (60's), prepares a snack.
Where's Zach?
Fired again?
I don't want to talk about it.
The first thing I learned when I retired was that time management is an asset.

FIVE diverse MEN, including Rick, stand against the wall. the other side of the mirror Detective Johnson sits with LADY IN BLACK (30's). A black veil streams from her hat covering her eyes, circa 1930's.
Take your time, Ma'am. We need you to be certain.
Can I see their profiles?
Detective Johnson keys a microphone.
Turn to your left. The men follow their instruction.
I just... I just don't know...
Back to front.
Three men turn to face forward. The other two turn to fac the wall.
All of you face forward. The two turn forward.
Number three...
Are you sure?
Could you have him step forward?
The Detective keys his microphone again.
Number three take two steps forward.
Rick steps forward and the lights dim on the other four. Caught in the spotlight, Rick squints from the brightness The lady in black shifts in her seat. A long beat.
That's him.
You're positive?
I'm positive. That's the man that needs to be in custody.
The detective keys his microphone once again.
Okay number three step back. Rick does as he's told.
Turn to your right --- all of you...
The group follows the detective's instruction.
...and exit.
One by one the men filter through the door. Rick EXITS.

Rick ENTERS on stage. The entire theater is cast in shade gray. The stage is barren. There is no audience. He looks around for a moment and as he reaches center stage is onc again flooded with the spotlight. Rick uses his arm to sh his eyes. SFX: A SOFT DIN OF VOICES. Looking stage left R realizes TWELVE JURORS have appeared in their box. A smal AUDIENCE has congregated. SFX: THE DIN SWELLS TO A QUIET CHAOS. A RAPPING of a gavel and Rick's attention swings t white haired JUDGE (70's).
Order in the court.
The noise level wanes, but not completely. Another RAP of gavel.
Order in the court, I say.
Focused on the Judge, Rick doesn't notice THE PROSECUTOR approaching from stage right.
Carrying a folding chair in one hand, notes and manila folders in the other, he sets the chair behind Rick.
Have a seat.
Do you know why you're here today, Mr. Stevens?
Why am I here?
Are you being rhetorical?
Are you asking me?
You stand here today an accused man.
Accused? Accused of what?
You have been placed in custody of your children.
Huh?
Your children, Mr. Stevens. You do realize you have children, don't you?
Yes, but...
But nothing Mr. Stevens, either you have children or you don't.
I do.
So, you accept responsibility for bringing young life into the world?
I guess...
PROSECUTOR
There's no guessing, Mr. Stevens, either you're responsible for siring offspring or you aren't. RICK
I am, but I'm not sure it was responsible. PROSECUTOR
A crime of passion, Mr. Stevens? How convenient. (A beat) And you accept the consequences of said actions? RICK
Why am I here? PROSECUTOR
Why are you here, Mr. Stevens? Why are you here? I'll tell you why you're here. Are you familiar with Ms. Cynthia Stevens? RICK
Yeah, she's my wife. PROSECUTOR
Was your wife, Sir. Was your wife. She recently filed for divorce. Were you aware of that? RICK
No, no I wasn't. PROSECUTOR
Well, she did. She also named you as her coconspirator in the act of having children. Were you aware of that, Mr. Stevens? RICK
Again, no. PROSECUTOR
Mr. Stevens, you just told the court that you aware you had children. You have also admitted that Ms. Cynthia Stevens was, in fact, your wife. (MOR E)
PRO SECUT OR (cont'd) On top of that you told this court that you accepted the responsibility of having said children, did you not?
Yes, but...
Then why, Mr. Stevens, do you continue to deny culpability in this situation?
Rick realizes the audience has swelled to nearly a full house. Beads of sweat form on his brow.
Answer the question.
Answer the question.
Like a trapped animal, Rick looks for his escape.
The question, Mr. Stevens.
How can you be sure it was me?
The audience hisses. The Judge RAPS his gavel.
She picked you out of a lineup, Sir. What more do you need?
Time.
Time is not an option, Mr. Stevens. Time --- is not --- an option.
A look of sad resignation crosses Rick's face.

You don't deny being married to Ms. Stevens, nor do you deny the act of procreation. You seem to understand that your actions bear consequence. You seem to understand that with parenthood, came responsibility.

PRO SECUT OR (cont'd) It seems to me, as it should to anyone with the capacity for simple deduction that you, Mr. Stevens, did willingly and knowingly enter into the commitments of parenthood fully aware of the potential pratfalls. Did you not?
Yes, yes I did.
It's time to pay the piper, Mr. Stevens. (To the Judge) It is the recommendation of the State that Richard C. Stevens been sentenced to the fullest capacity allowed by law.
What about Cindy?
Excuse me?
My ex, Cindy, what about her responsibilities to the children?
The Prosecutor moves to Rick and whispers in his ear.
She cut a deal, Rick. You were the one we wanted. You were the one we got. She took the plea. Sure, it costs her financially. But what is freedom worth?
A CLAMOR begins to rise from the crowd as they talk among themselves. The RAP of the gavel.

I see no reason to extend this any further. Mr. Stevens you have been found competent by the State and by this Court. You are completely cognizant of your surroundings, and you leave me no choice. This court finds you guilty as charged.
Guilty of what?
You are hereby remanded to custody of your children for no less than a lifetime. This Court is adjourned.
A GASP in the audience mixed with CHEERS. Rick appears dumbfounded. A BAILIFF approaches Rick and begins to lead off stage. Rick scuffles and struggles. The Judge stands begins to collect his files.
I can't do this alone. Don't make me do this alone. I'll never make it...
If you can't do the time, Mr. Stevens, then don't do the crime.
Mrs. Nelson ENTERS the kitchen carrying a book. She hands book to Melanie.
Highly Effective Strategies of Time Management for the Single Parent?
Learn it. Live it.
It was written by a man... a married man.
Lots of single parents are married.

Rick sits alone, his head hung low. A JAILER, (40's) approaches leading THREE YOUNG CHILDREN to the cell. KRIS (8), is followed by PHILLIP, (6), and NICHOLAS, (4). The swings open. The children run to their father.
Daddy!
RICK
Hi guys. PHILLIP
I love you daddy. RICK
I love you too, Phillip. NICHOLAS
I love you more. RICK
I love you more. NICHOLAS
I love YOU more. KRIS
Daddy, how come you're in jail? PHILLIP
Is this where we live? KRIS
When can we see mommy? RICK
Come here guys. I want to talk to you. The boys gather round. PHILLIP
What's wrong Daddy? RICK
I don't know when we're going to see your mom again. KRIS
Is she okay? RICK
She's kind of mad at daddy. NICHOLAS
Mommy mad at me too? RICK
No, baby, not at all. Your mom needs time to work through some things. So, for awhile, it's just going to be us...
What's she need time for?
To figure out who she is, where she's going, what she wants.
I miss mommy.
She misses you too, baby. And this isn't permanent... we're going to fight this... we're going to appeal. We'll take it to the Supreme Court if we have to.
You don't want us either?
Of course I want you. I just don't think I should have to do this alone.
The jailer still lingers in the doorway, leaning against bars.
I feel for you, I really do, but I've seen your kind before. You're a lifer. Whether it's fair or not. Whether justice was served. It doesn't matter. You're here for the duration.
The boys cling to their father. The CLANK of the door bei closed. The Jailer WHISTLES a sad spiritual as he walks a
Melanie sits on her couch and cries. Zach ENTERS.
What's wrong mommy?
Nothing.
Why are you crying? Did I do something wrong?
Nothing at all baby.
(Pulling a book from an end table) Tell me a story?
The camera pulls back to reveal that the room is really a well furnished cell.
Once upon a time, a very long time ago...
Kids and toys are strewn across the floor. Rick wears a h shade of facial growth. He reads The Genealogy of Morals. Jailer stands at the cell door.
Get yourself cleaned up.
Huh?
You have visitors... in the courtyard.
Shaved and wearing sunglasses, Rick approaches his parent He reaches his FATHER, (60's), first.
Quite the pickle you've got yourself in.
So it seems.
Rick's MOTHER gives him a big hug.
She was no good for you. I knew it from the start.
Mom, don't... okay?
Just saying...
I know, but what's done is done.
The children notice their grandparents and run to greet t They tackle their grandfather's legs.
There's my boys.
Grandpa. Rick and his mother sit at a picnic table while boys play with their grandfather.
You're dad and I are here for you.
I know mom.
Are you eating?
Yeah, I guess.
Do you need anything? Food? Money?
Watch the kids one night? I could use some time to myself.
Um... Yeah... okay... I suppose that would be all right... we'd have to ask your father, but I don't see why that would be a problem. (a beat) Other than that everything's okay?
We're okay...

Because it doesn't have to be like this. Mary Ryan, a friend of mine, her son had the same thing happen to him. Wife just up and left with no warning at all. He didn't waste a day. No sir, he was up and at `em almost instantly. You can leave here, you know? Mary Ryan's son did.
I like it here, mom.
What's to like? It's dingy and filthy. It's no place to raise children.
It's home and it's stable. The one thing the boys need right now is stability.
You can't keep hiding forever.
It's been five days, mom. I'm not hiding. I just need time to adjust.
Mary Ryan's son thinks you're hiding.
Do I know this guy?
Rick's mother slides a business card across the picnic ta
No, but I think you should. I hate that woman. How can a mother abandon her kids? How could she do this to my babies?
Rick looks to a blue sky.

CU. on a wad of blue cotton candy. Pull back to reveal Ci and her new beau, SCOTT, (30's) and leather clad. Danger personified. Cindy walks, focused on her cotton candy. Sh doesn't realize that Scott has stopped to watch a HOTTIE past. The two exchange a flirtatious glance.
Scott? Scott?
(Catching up) Yeah baby?
I hope she's living in hell too.
Melanie looks through the want ads. Some jobs are already circled.
What ya doing?
Looking for a job.
I know what you could do.
What's that?
You could stay home with me.
What do you pay?
Zach reaches deep in his pocket and pulls out a few coins counts them.
Sixty-five cents.
A day?
A week.
You can afford that?
If it keeps my mommy home with me.
Rick sits across the desk from FRANK RYAN, (40): An uncou Italian man who seems content to stuff his face with a submarine sandwich and speak through his mastication.

So, needless to say, I understand your situation. My old lady, she took off and left me with the kids five years ago. That bitch. But I'm not bitter or anything. I found me a good day care and moved on with my life. You should too.
It's hard...
Of course it's hard, sometimes feels like you're in prison, but you gotta be a man... stand up for yourself... provide for your family.
And you can help?
Me? I'll put ya to work. Some long hours, but it all pays off. Keeps you off the welfare system if ya know what I mean.
Yeah.
I'd rather pay you than pay the government to pay you. You can start Monday.
Rick stands to leave.
Here's the number to the day-care. Tell them you know me, they'll cut you a break.
The clock reads 5:45 when Rick pulls into the day-care parking lot.
Rick and the boys follow MS. HEATH on the guided tour.

And when school starts we have a bus service that will take the two oldest to and from school. We have story hour at Eleven, lunch at noon, and nap time at Twelve- thirty. Rest assured our programs are designed to be nurturing, caring environments that provide the parental guidance your children need in those hours you can't be with them. So, are there any questions?
No, you seemed to cover everything. Ms. Heath bends down to the kid's level.
You're going to like it here.
The kids grab Rick's leg. Nicholas cries.
No, daddy, don't leave us here.
Ms. Heath looks up to Rick.
(Reassuringly) They'll be just fine.
Rick pushes a broom as the clock unwinds.
Melanie sits in front of her FIRST INTERVIEWER.
I'm sorry. It would be really nice to have you on board, but you're just a little too qualified.
The children are into everything. There appears to be absolutely no rules.
Rick eats his lunch.
The children are engaged in a food fight.
Melanie sits in front of her SECOND INTERVIEWER.
Too Qualified.
Rick fumbles with his keys as he unlocks his car door.
Melanie sits in front of the THIRD INTERVIEWER.
Over qualified.
The children run around in their underwear, Nicholas in diapers, as the PROVIDER launders their clothes.
Melanie sits in front of the FOURTH INTERVIEWER.
You're just not qualified.
The clock reads 7:55 as Rick shuts off his car and opens door.
Melanie sits in front of the FIFTH INTERVIEWER.
I don't think I've seen such a perfect candidate.
The provider is hurriedly scrubbing the children's faces hands.
TRACKING BESIDE, Rick reaches the door and opens it.
Melanie leans forward in her seat.
Really?
The children are crying.
You are bad, bad children.
Rick approaches the room. STEDICAM on Rick's face
CU. on Fifth Interviewer.
Education level. Work experience. You really fit the billet.
As Rick ENTERS the children run to him.
So, did everything go okay?
They were angels.
Did you have fun boys?
The boys look to the provider who has a nasty scowl on he face.
We love it.
Rick loads the kids into the car.
The boys GIGGLE as they rough house in the back seat.
Get those seat belts on. The kids reluctantly comply.
So, how was your day?
We're hungry.
Didn't they feed you? They said they would feed you. The brochure said meals provided.
We didn't eat nuffin.
Daddy, I'm hungry.
CU. on Melanie. She appears relieved.
Unfortunately we filled the position earlier today. WHIP PAN to cell doors slamming closed.
Rick pulls through the drive-thru, takes his order from a smiling EMPLOYEE, and doles out the grub the as he drives off.
The kids aren't interested in eating. French-fries are fl everywhere.
Rick stands in a doorway. Frank fingers through a file cabinet.
So, how was your first week?
Thirteen hours a day doesn't leave me much time for my kids, But a job's a job, right?
Now you're talking.
Frank finds Rick's check and smiles as he hands him his laurels.
Two hundred and fifty bucks?
Pretty good, huh?
Two-hundred-and-fifty-bucks?
Don't spend it all in one place.
I give you sixty-five hours of my time and you give me two hundred fifty bucks?
It's the American way. This country was founded on low paying, back breaking, long hour jobs. Why, work like this makes you a bona fide patriot. Ya gotta love it.
(Mumbling as he EXITS) What's not to love?
Ready to leave, the boys goof in the hallway. In the offi Rick waits patiently as Ms. Heath tallies up the weekly totals.
That will be two hundred seventy- five dollars and thirty-six cents.
I'm a little short.
Rick takes the money from his pocket and hands it to Ms. Heath.
We take checks too.
Checks?
Those things you use when you don't have money.
I'm sorry, I'm clueless. My wife handled the checks.
Ah.
Does it help that I know Frank Ryan? He told me to mention his name.
You know Frank?
I work for him.
Ms. Heath looks back to her books.
That changes everything.
Great.
Two hundred ninety-five dollars and thirty-six cents.
Huh?
Frank owes me money and one way or another, I will collect.
So, I'm forty-five dollars short...
And thirty-six cents. Don't worry about it. It's your first week. You didn't know, so, we'll let it ride and just add it to next week's balance. A beat as Rick turns to leave.
You know there is a way you could save quite a bit of money.
Really?
Potty train the toddler.
Ms. Heath pulls some literature from her desk drawer.
Potty train? Nicky?
(Handing Rick the pamphlet) The toddler.
Melanie sits at a computer.
Mommy?
Yes, baby?
When are we going to have a normal life.
We do have a normal life... for us.
I mean when are we going to be like other people?
She pulls a flyer from the printer. CU. on flyer: BABY
Rick and Nicholas sit on the cot. Rick reads to himself. Nicholas looks at the pictures.
Big boy go potty.
Are you a big boy?
Huge-mong-gus.

Rick and the boys are in the baby isle. Rick picks up a p of Pull-Ups studies it for a moment and throws it in the cart. On a community bulletin board he sees a flyer for b sitting. He pulls the flyer, folds it and stuffs it in hi pocket.
Rick sets Nicholas on the potty.
Big boys go potty on the potty, Nicholas. Nicholas go potty on the potty?
Nicky shakes his head no.
You're brothers go potty on the potty. Daddy goes potty on the potty. Nicholas go potty on the potty?
Nicky shakes his head again no again.
Daddy will buy Nicky a toy from the store.
Okay.
If Nicky goes potty on the potty.
Nicky shakes his head no and begins to cry.
I want a toy!
Rick and the boys are in the toy isle. Nicholas has a hug grin on his face and a big toy in his hand. Rick takes th toy and tosses it in the cart.
Nicky stands in front of his father.
I have to go potty?
Rick sits up abruptly.
Really?
All done.
Rick is in Ms. Heath's office again.
How's the potty training coming?
I think we're making progress.
Three hundred forty and...
Seventy-two cents. Here's two- fifty.
You're still short.
I know and I'm working on that.
May I remind you that we're not a charity? If you need credit go to a bank. I run a reputable business and I need the balance by next Wednesday, or maybe you should consider other arrangements.
Phillip runs into the office crying. Blood streams down h head. Kris follows close behind.
I didn't do it.
Rick, Kris and Nicky sit patiently. Rick's Mother and Fat BURST through the doors.
What happened? Where is he? Is he going to be okay?
He's going to be fine. They're working on him now. From what they told me it's just a few stitches.
Boys will be boys. A NURSE peeks out.
Mr. Stevens can you come back? The doctor could use your help in calming the child down.
Mom?
Just go. I'll watch these two.
Phillip is in a halo. The DOCTOR appears perplexed as he stands near the child. Rick ENTERS.
Thank God.
How can I help?
Well, I need to give him a local so that I can sew the laceration, but he's not cooperating. Maybe hold his hand and distract him?
Rick moves to Phillip.
Hi little buddy.
Hi Daddy.
I need you to be a good boy, okay?
Okay daddy.
So, did you have fun today.
Uh huh.
Did you play with all your friends?
Uh huh.
The doc injects the child.
That fuckin' hurts!
Phillip!
But daddy, it does.
That's a big people word. You're a little people, and little people don't use big people words.
Okay.
(To Doctor) I'm sorry.
The doctor offers a smug smile and begins to sew the cut.
Do that again and my daddy's going to kick your ass.
Phillip runs down the hall with a huge butterfly bandage his head. He stops to chat with all the NURSES. Rick walk few steps behind carrying his coat. The doctor hurries to catch up with Rick.
Look I'm really sorry.
Can I ask you something?
Rick shifts uncomfortably.
Sure, I guess.

My son's a wuss. He cries over hangnails. My wife and I have tried everything to toughen him up, but nothing works. I was wondering if our kids could play together. Maybe some of Phillip's "boy" would rub off on Junior.
Rick stands at the counter. The boys rough house with the grandparents in the background.
Insurance?
Yeah, Insurance. That thing that covers medical emergencies?
I don't think I have any.
Everybody has insurance.
I don't think I do.
Okay.
The receptionist slides a bill across the desk. From Rick POV: the bill he holds shows a balance due of
Can I run a tab?
You don't have a check?
Rick walks with his mother. The boys and their Grandfathe are a few steps ahead.
I'm not even responsible for myself. How am I suppose to raise three kids?
It can be done.
I don't see how.
Find a way. Everything happens for a reason. God doesn't abandon his children, and neither will you.
God doesn't pay day-care.
There are other things out there... less expensive ways.
Could you watch them?
Oh... uh... well... I don't think your father is willing to do that. We raised our kids, Rick.
How `bout tonight, so I can catch a breath?
What? My watching them while you were in there with Phillip wasn't enough? Make me feel guilty.
I'll just ask God to watch them. He never abandons his children.
Rick's mom reaches in her purse and pulls some bills from wallet.
Take this.
I don't want your money mom.
Take the money.
As Rick puts the money in his pocket he finds the flyer.
Nicky sits on the potty.
I can't do it Daddy.
You can do it.
I can't do it.
Would you do it for a nickel?
I can't do it.
Rick lifts the child from the toilet.
Watch daddy.
Rick stands in front of the toilet and relieves himself. Nicholas watches by his side. He finishes and zips himsel up.
Daddy go potty in the potty.
Daddy?
Yes, Nicky?
I peed.
Rick's POV: A puddle on the floor. A RAP on the cell door Rick turns around to find MELANIE (24) looking in.
Hi.
I'm Melanie... The baby-sitter...
Oh, right, I'm glad you could...
My daddy has a big pee-pee.
I was just demonstrating the art of...
It's okay. I saw.
(Mumbling) Great.
Melanie ENTERS the cell followed by Zach.
You have a kid.
So do you.

Not criticizing, just surprised. I don't believe anyone at their old day-care had kids. If they did they kept them in a closet and only brought them out on special occasions. Christmas, Easter, an occasional birthday, and maybe when they had friends over for dinner, but only as a status symbol. It was like they'd say, "Here's the white picket fence. Here's the SUV. Here's the dog. Oh yes, here's the 2.5 children. Kids you can get back in the closet now."
You'd could make a fortune with a Renta- Kid business.
That has potential.
I've often thought of renting mine. Why pay for a baby-sitter when thousands of people would pay good money to set your kid on the mantle for a few hours?
So, what's his name?
I'm Zach.
Rick drops to a knee and extends his hand.
Hello Zach. I'm Rick.
You're old.
You got me there. I am old.
How old?
Older than dirt. When I was a kid we didn't have dirt. We had rocks and we had hammers. If we wanted dirt we banged a few rocks with really big hammers, and then we had dirt.
Worked the chain gangs?
You're too old for my mom.
Kris and Phillip who have been sitting in the corner real they have visitors and spring to greet them.
This is Kristian. This is Phillip, and the little guy from the potty, is Nicholas. Guys, this is Zach and...
Mel.
Mel.
The four boys run OS to play.
Beautiful kids.
Thanks. So's your's.
Ever try Cheerios?
Huh?
For potty training. Give him something to aim at. Drop a Cheerio or two in the toilet and let him pee away.
I'll have to try that. So, any questions about the job? Melanie moves towards the boys.
I'm going to go talk to them for a little bit. I'll let you know.
Melanie crouches to the boy's level. They appear to take real shine to her. Nicholas hands her a book, and the fou them move to the cell cot. The boys gather round.
My mom tells great stories.
We don't have a mom.
That's okay, I don't have a dad.
Once upon a time...
The cot morphs into a sofa. The dingy cell morphs into a lit room. Rick watches from a doorway.
The end...
Read it again. Read it again. Read it again.
I'm gonna talk to your dad.
Please.
We'll read another one in a little bit.
You have a real knack there.
Not a knack really. It's just about finding hope in places there should be none.
Whatever it is, I've never seen them take to a woman like that. Melanie smiles.
You want the job?
I'd like that.
Rick is pushing his broom when a gorgeous blond WOMAN wal past. They exchange long flirtatious looks.
Melanie is fixing the boys sandwiches.
Rick and the woman sit eating lunch.
You're really funny... and kinda cute.
Maybe we should...
Go out sometime? I'd like that. When?
I don't know... maybe...
Tonight?
Melanie on the phone.
No problem.
The boys run to her as she hangs up.
Who was that?
That was your daddy.
I love daddy.
Is he coming home?
No, he's going to be late. He has a date.
They all snicker.
So, I guess you have to deal with me a little while longer.
Yeah!
Melanie chases them in circles. They fall in a pile and wrestle.
Rick picks at his food. The woman has barely touched her plate.
You're a single father? That's wonderful. So many men refuse to accept any responsibility for their kids. So, how many do you have?
Um... three.
That's amazing. I'm sure they're just angels.
The boys jump on a bed.
Rick appears completely devoid of the conversation.
My sister has three. She said when the second one was born it doubled the work. She didn't realize the third would double the work load would again. And to think you do it all by yourself.
Um... kinda.

You're a terrific man. Did I tell you I love kids? They love me. It just comes so instinctively even though I've never had kids myself. I get lots of practice with my nephews though. So, when can I meet your boys?
Kris stands with arms crossed and scowling. His posse of brothers does the same. Kris POV: Looking up at the Woman crouching down to him and smiling.
You're not my mom.
Yeah!
Rick motions for the check.
You can't.
Rick flees on foot. The Woman gives chase.
Melanie tucks the boys into bed.
Rick sits with WOMAN 2.
A guy like you is so hard to find. I think I love you and I think you need to love me too.
Rick jumps into his car, locking the doors behind him. Wo tugs at the door handle as he drives away.
Melanie pours two glasses of wine.
Rick and WOMAN 3 are engaged in a deep kiss. They fumble through the door.
Melanie lights a candle on a table set for two.
Rick and woman 3 tear off each other's clothes.
Melanie finishes eating alone and blows out the candle.
Woman 3 rests her head on Rick's shoulder.
That was incredible.
Yeah.
I know I haven't known you very long, but I there's something I need to say...
The woman, wrapped in sheets, runs down the street. Rick to the door and catches himself in the jamb.
(Calling out) Was it something I said?
Melanie washes the dishes.
Rick drives home in silence.
Melanie's asleep on the sofa. Rick kneels beside her. He lightly runs his fingers through her hair stirring her slumber.
Did you have a good time?
Yeah, it was good... kinda okay... pretty much sucked.
What happened?
Why can't I find a woman like you?
You're trying too hard.
I feel bad for the boys. They don't have a "mom". She'll always be their mother, but she'll never be their mom.
Quit trying so hard. You're forcing issues that can't be forced. Relax. Everything happens when and how it's suppose to. It's about spirit and finding the will to love again, for you and the boys.
Melanie sits up and puts on her shoes.
You want to stay and...
I'm going to get...
Going?
Yeah.
You sure?
Positive.
A beat as they study each other's eyes.
Daddy, I have to potty.
I'll see you tomorrow.
Ok.
Melanie EXITS. Rick turns to tend to Nicky. He stops for moment then heads to the kitchen for a handful of Cheerio
Rick is on his hands and knees wiping the floor around th toilet.
Nicky almost do'd it.
Almost, baby boy. Almost.
Rick walks against the flow of the CROWD. As if in a drea everywhere he looks he sees Melanie. Every woman has her face.
The lights STROBE in rhythm to the music. Rick sits with and his wife CARRIE SILVERSTEIN.
Finally had to grow up?
Yeah, I...
You've got direction.
I suppose. I don't know if you'd call it direction, but there's a definite sense of purpose.
Good for you.
Yeah, but is it good for the kids?
Do the kids have direction?
Kris is in pushup position. Rick is dressed as a Gunnery Sargent.
Only two kinds of people make it in this world, boy; Those that are smart and those that are strong. If you don't want to be smart and do your homework then you can be strong and do pushups.
Rick stirs to reality.
I'm probably not as demanding of them as I should be.
You have to instill a sense of direction at a very early age.
The entire family sits eating dinner. Rick's Mother looks Phillip.
So, Phillip what do you want to be when you grow up?
Phillip studies Rick for a moment. Rick nods an approval.
Daddy says I can do three things when I grow up.
And what are those? Phillip takes a deep breath.
I can go to college and move the hell out of his house. I can join the military and move the hell out of his house, or I can get a job and...
... move the hell out of my house.
Rick!
Rick shakes his head.
Ya gotta let them be what they're going to be.
No, you have to mold them early. If you don't mold them they'll grow up to be Democrats.
And you do this with your kids?
That's not the point, is it, Carrie?
I think Rick is doing a wonderful job.
It's a struggle, going at it alone, but...
Carrie stands.
Excuse me, gentleman, I need to powder my nose.
Carrie walks off.
I can't believe you.
What?
Whining about being single. Married men would kill to be in your situation!
I'm just saying it's hard.
You have your sons to raise without feminine interference. Do you understand the significance of your situation? Do you understand the power in your circumstance?
Rick and the boys play baseball with an empty wrapping pa roll and a dirty sock.
Rick takes a swig of his beer.
Men, all over the world, would kill for that kind of power.
Rick and the boys head out the door with fishing poles in tow.
John isn't letting this soapbox go.
You have the kids and she pays child support... and you sit here and whine about things being hard? Give me a break.
It does have its advantages, I suppose.
Rick and the boys sit in front of the TV watching footbal Rick has a beer in his hand. The boys drink root beer fro beer mugs.
John realizes the beer bottles are empty.
Another?
Uh...
On me.
Sure.
John heads to the bar. Carrie approaches the table.
He went to grab a couple beers.
You know Rick, someday some girl is going to realize what a good man you are.
Carrie, I don't even have the funds to buy my own beer.
Love isn't about money. Love is about truth and selflessness and discovering who you are and who'll be. Someday, someone will find you.
Melanie talks on the phone. Rick pulls her from her seat.
I'll call you back.
Melanie fumbles the phone. A beat as they look into each other's eyes.
What?
Rick pulls her in for a kiss.
What was that for?
For finding me.
Rick and Melanie sleep in each other's arms. Nicholas sta at the bed.
Have to potty, daddy.
Rick stirs.
Go potty, buddy.
Nicholas holds the box of Cheerios.
Rick sits straight up to the sound of Nicky's CRY and RUNNING WATER.
An empty box of Cheerios on the floor and Nicky ankle dee water.
Frank sits at his desk.
I thank you for everything, but it's time to move on.
Where are you going? What will you do?
I don't know, Frank, but I'm worth more than this.
Rick places his paycheck on Frank's desk and EXITS into t hall. The corridors ECHO as Rick walks away.
You'll never make it without me!
Rick is strutting his way into a new job. He's dressed we
Rick sits at his new desk arranging a few personal. He le far back in his chair and clasps his hands behind his hea
Melanie, Rick and the boys fly a kite on a summer's day.
Melanie, Rick and the boys are eating pizza. Tears stream down Phillip's face.
Phillip, what's wrong?
Well, I wanted that piece and Kris took that piece, and I really, really wanted that piece.
What's so important about that piece?
It's bigger.
Zach grabs the pizza and stuffs it in his mouth. Phillip wails louder. Kris reaches for a pitcher of soda. A tussl ensues.
Easy on the drinks guys.
Arriving home Rick grabs an envelope that is taped to the door. Kris bolts through the door and heads to the bathro Phillip is crying again.

Rick opens the envelope and pulls out a note.
I gotta pee and Kris...
We're not going to fight over the bathroom. (Calling out)
RIC K (cont'd) Kris, your brother has to go too. Share!
Kris mopes back into the room. Phillip sticks his tongue at Kris. The boys EXIT.
What's that?
Rick looks up from his reading.
Huh? Oh, this? Nothing!
Rick balls the note and sticks it in his coat pocket.
Phillip and Kris stand side by side over the toilet. A be as Phillip looks at his brother.
This time mine's bigger.
Kris begins to cry.
STEDICAM on face as Rick ENTERS. Rick's POV: Cindy sits a table in the back. CU. on Rick as he approaches the table
I'm really glad you could make it.
Rick seats himself at the visitor's window. Can't really discern who sits on which side. He picks up the phone.
I took off work to be here.
Thank you.
So, what do you want?
I want to see your boys.
I don't think that's a good idea.
I'm their mother.
You forfeited that obligation, remember?
That's not fair!
You abandoned your kids!
I did not. I left them in the care of their loving father. There's a difference.
Is there?
I just want to see the boys.
You think they even know who you are?
I'm their mother.
You keep saying that.
I know things can never go back to the way they were before.
Rows of MEN are lined up outside the bedroom door. A MAN buttons his shirt and EXITS.
Next...
Cindy lies in bed smoking a cigarette.
Cindy appears impatient.
Rick? Rick? Rick?
Huh?
Let's keep the attorneys out of this and settle things like civil adults.
Rick watches Melanie and the boys play NINTENDO.
Hi guys.
Daddy! The boys run to their father. Melanie moves to Ric and gives him a kiss.
This is a surprise. Leave work to spend the day with us?
Come on guys. Someone is here to see you.
Rick? (A beat) Rick?
Rick leads the boys out the door. From Melanie's POV: Loo out a window as Rick loads the boys into their mother's c
Cindy closes the car door.
Thank you.
Three hours.
They'll be here.
Rick's POV: He watches Cindy back out and leave.
Melanie packs her things.
Where are you going.
Anywhere you're not.
What about the boys? What about me?
I'm all about second chances, but not when I come in second place.
What are you talking about?
Why was she here? What was that?
She's their mother.
Mother? I've been more of a mother than she ever was.
She's their mother.
Who willingly walked out of their lives.
She's their mother.
You keep saying that.

You think this is easy? You think raising these boys is something I want to do alone? Every day is like a prison sentence. Every thing I do, every decision I make is directly affected by the boundaries of my responsibility. I have three children, but I have no me. Everywhere I go people stare at me...
Dressed as dirty paupers, Rick and the boys hold tin cups to the PASSING BY.
Rick continues.
They stare at me, and I know what they're thinking...
A PEDESTRIAN drops a coin in ricks coffer.
You poor, poor man. You poor, poor children. How unfortunate to only have your father. How terrible it must be not to know your mother.
Melanie finishes packing her suitcase.

What about Zach? How noble of you to be the only single parent in the world. How stoic you are... so concerned with the best interests of your children. Too bad. Their best interest is walking out the door.
Melanie EXITS, SLAMMING the door behind her.
Against a burning sky, Rick waits in the drive. Cindy arrives. Her hair is strewed. The boys pile out of the ca and gather round their mommy. She kneels to their level.
When can we see you again?
Someday.
Is someday tomorrow?
Someday is someday, baby.
Give your Mom a hug, guys, then get in the house.
The boys hug their mom and then run to the door. A tear w in Cindy's eye.
I'm sorry.
For?
I thought things had changed.
But?
I am who I am, Rick. I'm not cut out to be a mommy.
I could have told you that.
I had to give it a shot. Rick turns to walk away.
Rick's POV: Sees the boys looking out the door. Rick turn back around to Cindy.

At whose expense? Huh, Cindy? At whose expense? Who's going to dry their tears tomorrow when they realize your never coming back? Who's going to rock them to sleep at night when they ask why mommy doesn't love them?
You are, and you wouldn't have it any other way.
A furious PULL BACK
ZOOM to Cindy standing in front of a door marked SOLITARY She steps in. The door SLAMS behind her.
Rick is donned in crisp business attire. He and the boys at the breakfast table.
Is Mel coming today?
I don't know, buddy.
Daddy?
Yes Nicky?
I love Mel.
She loves you too.
The clock unwinds.
Rick sits on the sofa his remote control in hand. Unkempt has a rough growth on his face.
Daddy... Daddy... Dad!
(Yelling) Don't you yell! If you have something to say, come here and tell me.
Kris ENTERS.
Dad?
Yeah?
Phillip's in the closet
Rick unlocks the closet door and lets Phillip out.
What were you doing in there?
Being Daddy.
Who locked the door?
Wasn't me...
I did.

Rick on the sofa. The boys gathered at his feet. He has a heavy growth of facial hair. He shirt is unbuttoned. His shoes have been discarded. He stares blankly forward. The boys lay sleeping at his feet. One by one PEOPLE show up begin to remove the furnishings. An open door allows SERV PROVIDERS to ENTER and disconnect. First the gas, then th telephone. CLOSE UP on a running faucet that slows to a trickle, then a drip, then dry. Rick's Mother and Father ENTER. She sits by her unresponsive son. Father lingers a distance.
Rick?... Rick?... Rick?
She stuffs a few dollars in his pocket as the CABLE GUY s up. The reception on the TV turns to snow.
Take care of my babies.
Rick never acknowledges her. She kisses him on the forehe and LEAVES.
Close in on a bed where Rick's parents lay.
What are you giving him money for?
To help him through the hard times. He's a good father, just having a rough go.
I've never met a good father that couldn't support his kids.
A MAN ENTERS to repossess the TV. PEOPLE continue to ENTE the house taking Rick's belongings.
CU. on Rick's mom.
You could watch the boys while he works.

I'm too old for that. The better side of life has passed me by. What if they fall? I don't hear like I used to. What if one of them was seriously hurt and I didn't hear their cry? I hate that the only thing I feel competent to do is give them money. I love my son and I love my grandbabies, but how would I live with myself if something happened to those children?
Slowly pulling up and away reveals another cell.
A REPRESENTATIVE from the electric company stands in fron Rick.
Sir, you're 3 months behind on your electric bill.
Rick reaches in his pocket and pulls the funds his Mother given him. The Rep. takes the cash.
It's a start, but not nearly enough.

The Rep. EXITS shutting off the lights behind him. The ST of a match, and a candle is lit. In the flicker of the fl Rick has a look of desperation. He holds a gun. Rick's PO Looking down on his sleeping children.
The HOWL of the wind and the candle is extinguished. A WA pierces the darkness and then a GUNSHOT.
A BANG against the bars wakes Rick and the boys.
I always knew you were a lifer.
Rick sits across the desk from an ADOPTION AGENT.
Because of their age it may take awhile. We'll start them out in foster care, but eventually they'll all be placed in loving, nurturing environments.

The boys are loaded in a wagon and pulled away from Rick an unrecognizable COUPLE. A small, hand-painted, sign tha hangs from the back of the wagon reads: BON VOYAGE. From Rick's POV: The boys move further and further away. Kris tries to christen the wagon with plastic bottled water. F the boy's POV: Their waving father fades in the distance.
Rick snaps back from his daydream.
They'll be together though, right?
Mr. Stevens, I wish I could make that promise, but the odds of an adoptive family willing to take them all is astronomical.
Rick stands.
Come on guys we're out of here.
Mr. Stevens?
I'm sorry, I made a mistake.

Rick sits at the picnic table reading a book. The boys ar off playing. Kris falls. He grabs his knee and cries. Ric drops his book and runs to the child. GUARDS on duty pay attention. Rick reaches the child. The injury appears rat serious.
(Calling out.) Can I get some help here.
His calls go unanswered. A tear forms in his eyes. Months of frustration boil in h face. A CONVICT passing by kneels by Rick.
Can you help me?
Can you help him?
I don't know.
What does he need?
I don't know.
He needs a father, not a book reading baby-sitter.
(In a hushed rage) I can't fucking do this.
Yes you can.
The convict runs his hand over the child's leg and everyt appears healed.
Use your mind and your heart. It's different than it ever should have been... but different isn't wrong.
But I...

Use what you have. There is a vein of wealth inside you just waiting to be mined. Think differently than you have ever thought before. Worker harder than you ever thought you could. Love these children like they've never been loved before.
How?

The answer lies within. Quit worrying about how these misguided events have torn your life apart. Quit dwelling on all of your misgivings. Look around you. You're not alone. But you, and you alone, will make the difference.

Rick notices his cell door is unlocked. He steps into the corridor. Rick's POV: Walking past cells he sees people h knows. His mother and father appear very old. Melanie is Mrs. Nelson's house. Zach clings to her leg. Carrie's ang John talks away his phone.

Rick and the boys wait for their caseworker. A pregnant W and her TWELVE CHILDREN sit a few seats away. Her face an clothes are as dirty as her children's. Rick looks at his watch, and then at her, and then back to his watch. He sl the watch off his wrist and hands it to her.
It's not worth a lot, maybe a few hundred bucks, but it might keep you in soap for a year.
A CASEWORKER comes to Rick.
Mr. Stevens, I can see you now. Rick and the Pregnant Woman lock eyes.

I ain't some charity case. I know what you think when you look at me. You think; Look at that poor, poor woman. Look at those poor, poor children. How unfortunate it must be that they only have a mother. How terrible it must be not to know their father.
Mr. Stevens?
I didn't mean it like that?
No one ever does.
Mr. Stevens?
Rick and the woman continue their stare.
Mr. Stevens? I can see you now.
I'm sorry, I'm going to have to reschedule.
Excuse me?
Responsibility calls.

Rick is reading from a large textbook and jotting in a notebook. He wears his glasses. His boys come to him. Tak a break from studying he lays his glasses on the table. T boys pile into his lap. Nicky holds a storybook.
Please daddy? Please? Rick opens the book so all can see.
Once upon a time...
The cell once again transforms into a small suburban hous One by one, things lost, are replaced.
Rick is eating pizza and looking through the want ads. A ads are already circled.
Daddy, I'm hungry.
Nicholas pulls his shirt up to reveal his stomach.
It's very, very empty.
Rick hands him what's left of his pizza. He takes a swig beer.
Daddy, I'm thirsty.
Rick takes a long look at his beer.
Get your coats on.
We're leaving guys.
Rick has a cart full of groceries at the check out line. OLDER WOMAN stands behind him. The CLERK rings up a final total.
Thirty-two hundred and fifty-six dollars.
Rick looks dumb founded.
Think it's bad now? Wait til they're teenagers.
Rick loads boxes of cereal, Kool-Aid, Spaghetti-O's, loav of bread and numerous other things into a trough. The boy dance in excitement.
Rick and his mother walk along.
Mom, I have an idea, but I need your help.
Rick's mom reaches in her purse.
Put your checkbook away. What I need you can't buy.
What do you need.
For you to believe in me.
Rick, his parents and the boys pound a sign into the fron yard that reads: "MOW `EM AND GROW `EM LAWN CARE 555-1616
Cindy is pushing a grocery cart when Melanie and her new BOYFRIEND pass. Melanie stops in her tracks, turns around after a brief beat, approaches Cindy.
I know you.
Excuse me?
Rick's ex-wife?
And you are?
Can I ask you a question? What is Phillip's favorite color?
Huh?
Blue. His favorite color is blue. How many teeth has Kris lost?
I don't know. Why?

Four. Two on top and two on bottom. He got a quarter for the first one, fifty cents for the next two and he parlayed the last into an even dollar. Nicholas cries at night because he thinks the house is filled with ghosts. Kiss him once on the forehead, once on the cheek and sing The Cradle Will Rock and he'll sleep the whole night through. Kris' favorite subject is math. He loves to read and write, but he doesn't do so well in social studies. He knows how to ride a bike. Why? Because I taught him. Phillip wants to learn but he's always afraid he'll fall. Nicky just likes to Flintstone his tricycle. Phillip's favorite cartoon is Tunenami.
MEL ANIE (cont'd) He's afraid of the dark and cries himself to sleep at night saying his mommy doesn't love him.
What's your point?
I'm more their mom than you'll ever be.
So, why are you here with slick and not with "your" kids?
A beat.
Things change.
Yeah... yeah they do. Now if you'll excuse me I need to find the asparagus. (A beat) I couldn't do it, ya know?
Melanie turns back around.
Do what?
I always thought I wanted to be a parent, and I was really good at being pregnant, but I sucked as a mom. I know that now. I don't have what it takes.
I don't think I've ever felt as much pity for anyone as I do for you right now.
Take care of my boys... all of them.
Rick and the boys stand by the river looking up a huge embankment. There appears to be no permanent trail. Looki up, scattered PEOPLE sit at different levels on the climb
Well, guys, I guess this is it.
We can do it daddy.
Yes we can.

Rick stretches out. The boys jog in place. Rick cracks hi neck. The boys crack their knuckles. In SLOW MOTION they begin their ascent, running wildly up the incline. Rick f flat on his face. Rick caries the boys. Phillip is draped across his should Nicholas hangs around his neck. Kris clings to Rick's leg is dragged with each step. They pass a weary CLIMBER who taken a moment to catch his breath.
You can do it.

Rick is using a push mower on this huge estate. Nicholas follows behind with a bubble mower.

The boys' do a victory dance at the top of the hill, thei arms extended far above their heads. Kris stops for a mom and then tugs at his father's shirt. Rick tries to ignore child but then stops mid-dance.

Kris points up.
Look daddy.
Rick is looking through college literature, insurance applications, and YMCA programs.
Rick holds a college pamphlet. Rick's POV: He looks at th pamphlet then up to see they aren't even close to the top They have just reached a plateau along the way.
We can do it.
(Through a weary voice.) Yes we can.
Rick wears his painter's pants. The boys are armed with a assortment of paintbrushes. Paint cans and ladders adorn room.
Rick and the boys continue their climb. The breaths are heavy, but they march steadily upward.
Rick and the boys, hand in hand, walk toward the church.
Rick stands back and looks at one finished wall. Kris mim his father, backing up to have a look for himself.
Kris!
Too late, Kris has tripped over a can of paint. As he sit his butt a look of fear crosses his face, a tear forms in eye. Rick takes his paintbrush and dots Kris on the nose.
Hey!
Phillip and Nicholas are quickly engaged in painting each other and a full-blown paint war ensues.
A CHOIR of voices sings.
Melanie and her boyfriend sit in silence. A beat.
What's wrong? What did I do?
Not you, it's me.
What then?
Melanie looks her boyfriend square in the eyes, runs her down his cheek.
I'm sorry.
Melanie EXITS the car and runs down the street.
Rick and the boys stop to rest. Kris throws a rock while is looking away. Rick looks up to find Phillip picking up stone.
Put the stone down.
But...
No buts: Put the stone down.
Off Screen SFX: A huge thud and someone rolling down the hill.
I knew this was a hard climb, but...
A RESTING CLIMBER appears.
Long way up.
Yeah.
Long way down for that matter.
That too.
A beat.
So, what's your point.
No point, just an observation. Drink?
The climber holds out a canteen.
I'm okay.
For the boys.
Daddy, I'm thirsty. Rick studies the climber for a moment.
Go ahead.
The climber hands the boys the canteen.
You know, if you stop here, halfway between a long way up and a long way down you really haven't accomplished much, have you?
We're not stopping. We're just resting.
That's what I said, fourteen years ago. Rick looks toward the top.
We can do this.
Yes you can.
A reinvigorated Rick hops to his feet.
We can do this!
Yes we can!
Rick is back on the stage. The audience is full.
What is so important Mr. Stevens that you would burden this court with convening today?
I just needed clarification.
On what, Mr. Stevens? On what?
I know if I have to, I can do this alone, but do I have to do this alone? A hushed MURMUR rises in the audience. The Judge RAPS his gavel on the bench.
Order in this court! A beat as things quiet down.
Your inquiry, Mr. Stevens? Is it in the best interest of the children or in the best interest of you?
I don't know.
He doesn't know. He just doesn't know.
I don't know.
Then this court sees no reason to amend the original verdict. The order stands.
But...
Tell it to someone who cares, Mr. Stevens.

I have. I have laid my heart out on the line time and time again, only to walk away empty handed. This love, this caring, this sharing of life, it's a sentence and my heart has been condemned. It doesn't matter who I've told, what's in my heart is never quite enough. The people I have cared for most have shunned me in life and in love. Unanswered phone calls... Unnoticed displays of affection... A rose that withers on the doorstep... No matter what I do, it's never enough. Just once, just one fucking time, I want to be enough.
Your only condemnation is self- pity. You have people that care all around you, but you're too blind to see them. If you don't pull yourself together soon, my friend, they soon will all be gone.

In B&W SLO-MO: Rick stands watching his sons play. The wi blows the leaves of a tree. The boys run further and furt out until they are out of sight. Rick calls out to them. Slowly, across the field, three young adults return. Rick now an old man, hunched over and aged with wrinkles. The three young men walk beside their elderly father, support him with each step.

Rick is holding flowers. The boys have an assortment of "instruments" to add a serenade. The music is a mishmash odd notes that could only be construed as music to a pare ear. Melanie stands on the front porch, her arms crossed.
What do you want?
I'm a proud man, sometimes foolish.
Go on.
I have a long way to go before I could ever be the man you need me to be.
And?
And I got confused between what I should have done and what I thought was right.
Yes you did.
I put you on a pedestal and then I knocked you down. It wasn't fair.
Life's not fair Rick.
You were more a mother to my boys than they have ever known. You were more a woman to me than I have ever deserved.
You're right.
You're not going to make this easy, are you?
Cut the bullshit, Rick.
Rick wraps his arms around Melanie and pulls her in for a hug.
(In Mel's ear) I can live my life alone. I can raise my kids alone. I can walk this path alone. I'd much rather do it with you.
Grabbing him by the collar she's torn. Melanie shakes her head.
I can't.
She turns to go inside.
Can't?
(Turning back around.) I won't.
I shouldn't have come here.
No, you shouldn't have.
Rick turns to leave.
You just don't get it do you?
Get what?
You're here for you, you selfish prick.
Melanie lays in bed covering her ears.

Days go by when I lose me. There are nights when I lay in bed and I can hear Zach through the walls. He's crying out for me, and I lay there motionless, wishing I was anyone but me, anywhere but here, thinking that somewhere, sometime, there has to be room for me. But that someday never seems to come. You're dangerous. Loving you means I lose me. And I will never lose let that happen.
MEL ANIE (VO) (cont'd) So, don't come knocking on my door, asking for my heart, if you don't have room for me.
Melanie ENTERS the house closing the door behind her. Ric tosses the flowers on the porch, turns and walks away. Th boys follow behind.
I could have looked sad.
I can look sad too.
But I look sadder.
I sad.
Nicholas starts to cry.
Rick falls flat on his face. He lays there motionless.
Don't quit, daddy.
Rick pounds the ground, pulls himself up, dusts himself o and with a determined look starts back up the hill.
Daddy doesn't quit.
Rick and John sit at the bar.
You love her?
I think so... I don't know.
If you think you're in love you are.
RICK
I suppose I am. JOHN
Does your heart skip a beat when she walks by? RICK
She's my best friend... or was. JOHN
Does your heart skip a beat when she walks by? RICK
Yes. JOHN
Do your palms sweat when you think about her? RICK
Yes. JOHN
Does she inspire you? RICK
With music and poetry. JOHN
And is there passion? RICK
There's fire. JOHN
And have you ever told her this? RICK
She knows. JOHN
Have you ever told her this? RICK
No. JOHN
Don't you think you should? RICK
It only confuses things.
Loving your best friend confuses things? I can't think of a love more lucid. Rick stands to leave.
You know I'll never forgive you for this, don't you? You had the power and the dream at your fingertips and you're giving it all away.
You didn't marry your best friend?
No.
I thought you had things all planned out.
Affairs of the heart and those of the mind are two different things.
It's not too late, you know?
With a shrug John drops to one knee in front of Rick.
Go Home, John. Go home and talk to your best friend the way you talk to me.
Rick BURSTS through the front door. His mother appears aghast.
I need you to watch the boys.
But you're father...
Rick's Father ENTERS.
Woman, enough.
But...
No more excuses. It's time to live life and enjoy our grandkids. (To Rick) Go. The boys will be fine.
Can't we just give him money to pay for a baby-sitter?
Rick BOLTS out of the house.
Melanie is working as a waitress. She's pouring coffee wh she sees Rick.
(To herself) Oh shit.
Whoa!
The cup has nearly reached the brim.
Sorry.
Pay attention, would ya?
Rick reaches her.
What do you want?
To talk.
I'm working.
I know.
Melanie is at the next customer who early awaits a refill but she doesn't pour.
So, where are the boys?
They're at my parents.
What? Not going to use them to try to persuade me with guilt?
Is that what you thought?
I have a son of my own. I know when people are using their kids.
Ma'am.
(To Customer 2) Excuse us for a moment okay?
I'd just like some coffee.
Melanie walks off. Rick grabs a cup from a recently vacat table and sets it in front of the patron.
(Calling out.) Excuse me, Miss?
What is your problem?
Cold.
What?
The coffee, it's cold.
Rick picks up the cup, pulls a lighter from his pocket an runs it several times under the mug.
(Setting the cup back down.) Quit your bitching.
Rick moves to Melanie.
I can't believe you came here.
I can't believe you're a waitress.
Beats chasing around after snot nosed brats all day.
I thought you liked my kids.
I was talking about you.
Melanie moves on. Rick gives chase. He catches her and sp her around spilling coffee all over the floor.
I deserved that.
So, what do the kids need? A babysitter? A surrogate mom?
This isn't about the kids.
Then what's it about?
It's about me, the selfish prick.
About you?
Hear me out, okay?
(Looking at her watch.) You have 15 seconds.
Okay, okay.
Ten.

Melanie, there is a grace about you that reminds me how clumsy I am. There is an honesty about you that reminds me how deceitful I can be. There is a beauty in your eyes that reminds me how ugly I've become. There is a kindness in your voice that contradicts my coarseness. There is a glow around you that illuminates my dullness. There is spirit in you that challenges my laziness, but most of all, there is a woman in you, that sparks my desire, a desire to be graceful and honest and beautiful and kind. A desire to be better than I am or ever thought I could be.
Go on.
I think my ten seconds are up.
Who's counting?
Miss... My coffee?
Melanie sets the coffee on a nearby table.
Get it yourself.
I love you.
I don't think I heard you.
If I give you my heart will you promise to treat it softly? Kiss it when it hurts? Put it in a box and know that it belongs to you?
That's not what you said.
I said I love you.
As brutal as that can be?
I love you. I love you, I love you, I love you.
I kind of like you too.
Rick comes to another plateau and finds Melanie waiting f him.
I never thought you'd make it.
Been waiting long?
I never thought you'd find me.
I had to find me first. I hope you plan on walking, cause I'm not sure I can carry you.
So, how do we do this? The two begin the ascent together.
One step at a time?
Side by side?
Maybe you could carry me?
Rick jumps in Melanie's arms. They tumble to the ground u his weight.
Rick packs his things in boxes. A knock at the door and t room morphs back into the cell.
Rick turns around to see the jailer standing at the door.
Getting out of here, huh?
It's time to move on.
If you leave don't ever come back.
Not even...
Not even on a visit. You're a very ugly man. I'd hate to explain to the other guards why you'd come to visit me.
Rick's Mom and the boys are playing.
Grandma?
Yes, Kris?
Grandma I love you.
I love her more.
I love her the whole universe.
I love you all the whole universe plus one.
Rick and Melanie walk across the stage.
So, this is where it all happened.

It's funny, the tricks the mind can play on you... but the Judge, he sat right over there... and the jury sat right there... and the audience was filled with all these people who didn't really give a shit about me.
A bunch of innocent bystanders?
And they all sat passing judgement on me, not knowing the situation, just staring over their schoolmarm spectacles and pointing their crooked fingers.
All the world's a stage.
Always casting dispersions.
Rick walks off leaving Melanie at center stage. She looks around. The faint echo of a Judge's gavel can be heard in distance.
Guilty as charged.
Did you hear that?
Hear what?
Nothing... nothing at all.
PAN reveals: Rick, Melanie, the boys, and John sit watchi ball game.
The secret of life, Melanie, is to always pay attention...
A pregnant Carrie returns to her seat carrying a box of hotdogs and drinks.
... always be prepared for what's right around the corner. The CRACK of the bat.
Duck!
Huh?
John's POV: A foul ball is screaming in his direction.
